16-2-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
16-2-1.indicator_name: Доля детей в возрасте от 1 года до 14 лет, в последний месяц подвергшихся любому физическому наказанию и/или психологической агрессии со стороны тех, кто обеспечивает уход за ними
16-2-1.graph_title: Доля детей в возрасте от 1 года до 14 лет, в последний месяц подвергшихся любому физическому наказанию и/или психологической агрессии со стороны тех, кто обеспечивает уход за ними
16-2-1.goal_name: Goal 16. Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels
16-2-1.target_name: 16.2. End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children
16-2-1.indicator_name1: 16.2.1. Proportion of children aged 1–17 years who experienced any physical punishment and/or psychological aggression by caregivers in the past month
16-2-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Department of Household Statistics)
16-2-1.definitions: Proportion of children aged 1-17 years who experienced any physical punishment and/or psychological aggression by caregivers in the past month is currently being measured by the proportion of children aged 1-14 years who experienced any physical punishment and/or psychological aggression by caregivers in the past month.
16-2-1.concepts: In Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS), psychological aggression refers to the action of shouting, yelling or screaming at a child, as well as calling a child offensive names, such as ‘dumb’ or ‘lazy’. Physical (or corporal) punishment is an action intended to cause physical pain or discomfort, but not injuries. Physical punishment is defined as shaking the child, hitting or slapping him/her on the hand/arm/leg, hitting him/her on the bottom or elsewhere on the body with a hard object, spanking or hitting him/her on the bottom with a bare hand, hitting or slapping him/her on the face, head or ears, and beating him/her over and over as hard as possible.
16-2-1.rationale_interpretation: All too often, children are raised using methods that rely on physical force or verbal intimidation to punish unwanted behaviours and encourage desired ones. The use of violent discipline with children represent a violation of their rights. Physical discipline and psychological aggression tend to overlap and frequently occur together, exacerbating the short- and long-term harm they inflict. The consequences of violent discipline range from immediate effects to long-term damage that children carry well into adulthood. Violent discipline is the most widespread, and socially accepted, type of violence against children.
16-2-1.data_sources: Household surveys such as UNICEF-supported MICS and DHS that have been collecting data on this indicator in low- and middle-income countries since around 2005. In some countries, such data are also collected through other national household surveys.
16-2-1.data_collection: UNICEF undertakes an annual process to update its global databases, called Country Reporting on Indicators for the Goals (CRING). This exercise is done in close collaboration with UNICEF country offices with the purpose of ensuring that UNICEF global databases contain updated and internationally comparable data. UNICEF Country Offices are invited to submit, through an online system, any updated data for a number of key indicators on the well-being of women and children. Updates sent by the country offices are then reviewed by sector specialists at UNICEF headquarters to check for consistency and overall data quality of the submitted estimates. This review is based on a set of objective criteria to ensure that only the most recent and reliable information is included in the databases. The updated databases are also posted online at data.unicef.org.
16-2-1.computation_methods: Number of children aged 1-17 years who are reported to have experienced any physical punishment and/or psychological aggression by caregivers in the past month divided by the total number of children aged 1-17 in the population multiplied by 100.
16-2-1.comments_limitations: Definitions of both physical punishment and psychological aggression will need to be very clearly defined for countries but this should not be a problem as there is a wealth of available literature and research on the violent punishment of children and General Comment No.13 on the Convention of the Rights of the Child (CRC) also provides a definition for “corporal” or “physical” punishment as well as “mental violence”.
16-2-1.data_availability_gaps: Nationally representative and comparable prevalence data are currently available for a sub-sample of children aged 1-14 years for 73 low- and middle-income countries.
16-2-1.disaggregation: Nationally representative and comparable prevalence data are currently available for a sub-sample of children aged 1-14 years for 73 low- and middle-income countries.
16-2-1.references_documentation: The Kyrgyz Republic SDG National Reporting Platform: https://sustainabledevelopment-kyrgyzstan.github.io

10-3-1-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
10-3-1-1.indicator_name: Number of complaints submitted to the Ombudsperson
10-3-1-1.graph_title: Number of complaints submitted to the Ombudsperson (written and oral)
10-3-1-1.goal_name: 10. Reduce inequality within and among countries
10-3-1-1.target_name: 10.3 Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard
10-3-1-1.indicator_name1: 10.3.1.1 Number of complaints submitted to the Ombudsperson
10-3-1-1.contact_name: Keremetkan Kelsinbek kyzy (Head of the Department of Reception of citizens' appeals and Documentation support)
10-3-1-1.definitions: The Ombudsman (Akyykatchy) considers applications and complaints from citizens of the Kyrgyz Republic, foreigners and stateless persons staying in the Kyrgyz Republic or their representatives, non-governmental organizations concerning decisions or actions (inaction) of state and local government bodies, state and non-governmental organizations, institutions, enterprises, officials, civil servants violating the rights and freedoms of citizens of the Kyrgyz Republic. human and civil liberties established by the legislation of the Kyrgyz Republic, international treaties and agreements, of which the Kyrgyz Republic is a participant.                                                      In 2019, 3,923 written appeals were received from citizens of the republic and from citizens of foreign countries addressed to the Akyikatchy (Ombudsman), of which 2,595 (66.1%) were sent to the Central Office of the Akyikatchy (Ombudsman) Of the Kyrgyz Republic. Among them, 220 (5.6%) are collective, signed by 1,784 people. In addition, 5,441 people received appropriate oral explanations, legal advice, and recommendations on which authorities they should contact to resolve the issue. The total number of citizens who applied in 2019 was 11 thousand 148 people.
10-3-1-1.data_availability_gaps: On the website http://ombudsman.kg / the annual report of the Akyykatchy (Ombudsman) of the Kyrgyz Republic is posted
10-3-1-1.disaggregation: Akyykatchy (Ombudsman) The Kyrgyz Republic keeps records of applicants by gender, age groups, geographical location, etc.
10-3-1-1.references_documentation: The National SDG Reporting Platform of the Kyrgyz Republic: https://sustainabledevelopment-kyrgyzstan .github.io

3-9-2.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
3-9-2.indicator_name: Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation and lack of hygiene (exposure to unsafe Water, Sanitation and Hygiene for All (WASH) services)
3-9-2.graph_title: Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation and lack of hygiene (exposure to unsafe Water, Sanitation and Hygiene for All (WASH) services)
3-9-2.goal_name: 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-9-2.target_name: 3.9. By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination
3-9-2.indicator_name1: 3.9.2 Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation and lack of hygiene (exposure to unsafe Water, Sanitation and Hygiene for All (WASH) services)
3-9-2.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Demographic Statistics Division)
3-9-2.definitions: The mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation and lack of hygiene (exposure to unsafe Water, Sanitation and Hygiene for All (WASH) services) expressed per 100,000 population.
3-9-2.concepts: Deaths attributable to unsafe water, sanitation and hygiene focusing on inadequate WASH services. The included diseases are the WASH attributable fractions of diarrhea (ICD-10 code A00, A01, A03, A04, A06-A09), intestinal nematode infections (ICD-10 code B76- B77, B79) and protein-energy malnutrition (ICD-10 code E40-E46).
3-9-2.rationale_interpretation: The indicator expresses the number of deaths from inadequate water, sanitation and hygiene (with focus on WASH services) which could be prevented by improving those services and practices. It is based on both the WASH service provision in the country, as well as the related health outcomes, and therefore provides important information on the actual diseases.
3-9-2.data_sources: Cause of death information is obtained from medical death certificates drawn up by doctors or mid-level medical personnel on disease, accident, homicide, suicide and other external influences resulting in death. These documents, along with civil registration of deaths drawn up by civil registry offices are sent to statistical agencies for calculation.
3-9-2.data_collection: Mortality data are obtained from the annual statistical compilation of official records of deaths drawn up by the civil registration offices (The Civil Registration Office of the State Registration Service under GKR). Aggregated data are collected and processed by the regional statistical offices and the National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic.
3-9-2.computation_methods: The number of deaths from unsafe water, unsafe sanitation and lack of hygiene (exposure to unsafe WASH services) in a year, current estimate. Calculated for 100,000 population.
3-9-2.comments_limitations: Get acquainted with coding rules for the primary cause of death and definitions set out in the revised International Statistical Classification of Diseases (ICD-10). In case of difficulties with diagnosis, contact staff of the E-Health Center of the Ministry of Health to consult for the final diagnosis. These data are key for improving health and reducing preventable mortality in the country.
3-9-2.quality_assurance: Logical and arithmetic control of recorded data is carried out. Data control in data records is carried out by logical control procedure embedded in the data input and processing software. The causes of death codes are checked along diagnoses recorded in death report, according to ICD-10, and results tables are analyzed for causes of death.
3-9-2.disaggregation:
Territorial data aggregation: country, region, district.
Data aggregation by sex: total, men, women.
3-9-2.international_comparability: International definition of the indicator is used for national statistics. Data coding and compilation on deaths by cause of death is done by state statistics authorities in accordance with the WHO International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Causes of Death (ICD-10), since 2000 report. By agreement with the National Statistical Committee, database on mortality is submitted to the Centre for Electronic Health of the Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic: form C52 «Population mortality by cause of death» submitted annually, in June following the reporting year.
3-9-2.references_documentation: References to RLA and methodology: http://www.stat.kg/ru/about/pravovye-osnovy-organov-gosudarstvennoj-statistiki/; https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/Metadata; http://www.stat.kg/ru/statistics/download/methodology/68/.

4-1-1-a.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
4-1-1-a.indicator_name: Number of children and adolescents aged 7–17 (grades 1–11) not enrolled in general education institutions
4-1-1-a.graph_title: Number of children and adolescents aged 7–17 (grades 1–11) not enrolled in general education institutions
4-1-1-a.goal_name: 4. Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4-1-1-a.target_name: 4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes
4-1-1-a.indicator_name1: 4.1.1.a  Number of children and adolescents aged 7–17 (grades 1–11) not enrolled in general education institutions
4-1-1-a.organization_name: The National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Social Statistics Division)
4-1-1-a.definitions: The number of children and adolescents aged 7-17 years (grades 1-11) who did not start classes in general education institutions for reasons of gender
4-1-1-a.concepts: Data are provided on the number of children and adolescents aged 7-17 who have not started classes in general education institutions and their age distribution. Information from the heads of organizations about the non-attendance of children and adolescents at a general education organization at the beginning of the school year is used, indicating the reason for non-attendance. The lists of children and teenagers who did not attend the educational organization, the heads of organizations are also provided to the state administration and aiyl okmotu. An analysis of data on children who did not start school revealed that the main reasons for non-attendance were the financial difficulties of families, increased family expenses for a child's schooling, unwillingness to learn from some teenagers, lack of transportation to school for children from remote areas, as well as seasonal agricultural work. Data on the reasons why children did not start school by region.
4-1-1-a.rationale_interpretation: The distribution of the number of children who have not started classes in educational institutions for reasons of non-attendance, such as "financial difficulties" shows the number of children who do not have shoes, clothes, etc. for example, “family circumstances” provides data on children looking after younger siblings, caring for the sick in the family (mother, father) or helping parents, “lack of language proficiency” should indicate the number of children who do not speak the language of instruction and the reason, “due to illness” children who do not attend educational institutions are indicated and because of a long-term chronic disease: polyarthritis, paralysis, tuberculosis and others, “children with disabilities”, data are provided on children who are blind, deaf, with disabilities of mental or physical development, The number of children who have not started classes is shown based on the conclusions of the medical and pedagogical commissions.
4-1-1-a.data_sources: State Statistical Reporting Form No. 77 "Report on the number of children and adolescents aged 7-17 who have not started classes in schools and other educational institutions at the beginning of the school year"
4-1-1-a.data_collection: Form No. 77 is provided by Aiyl Okmotu, district, city state administrations.
4-1-1-a.computation_methods: The total number of children who have not started classes is indicated, and logical and arithmetic control is also performed.
4-1-1-a.comments_limitations: Every child attends school, referring to this slogan, every citizen of the Kyrgyz Republic has the right to education, regardless of gender, nationality, language, social and property status, limited health opportunities, type and nature of occupation, religion, political and religious beliefs, place of residence and other circumstances.
4-1-1-a.quality_assurance: After filling out the report, logical and arithmetic control is performed.
4-1-1-a.data_availability_gaps: Publications in the education and science authorities of the Republic of Kazakhstan, http://www.stat.kg/ru/publications/sbornik-obrazovanie-i-nauka-v-kyrgyzskoj-respublike/
4-1-1-a.disaggregation: By region, gender, age, and reasons for not attending classes
4-1-1-a.references_documentation: The National SDG Reporting Platform of the Kyrgyz Republic: https://sustainabledevelopment-kyrgyzstan .github.io

8-1-1-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
8-1-1-1.indicator_name: Gross domestic product per capita (in US dollars)
8-1-1-1.graph_title: Gross domestic product per capita (in US dollars)
8-1-1-1.goal_name: 8. Promote sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all
8-1-1-1.target_name: 8.1 Sustain per capita economic growth in accordance with national circumstances and, in particular, at least 7 per cent gross domestic product growth per annum in the least developed countries
8-1-1-1.indicator_name1: 8.1.1.1 Gross domestic product per capita (in US dollars)
8-1-1-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Department of Economic Statistics and National Accounts)
8-1-1-1.definitions: GDP per capita is the nominal amount of gross domestic product produced per person over a certain period of time.
8-1-1-1.concepts:
Gross domestic product (GDP) is the most important indicator of national accounts, characterizing the state and development of the economy and economic growth trends of the Kyrgyz Republic over a certain period.  It reflects the value of goods and services produced in a country and intended for final consumption, accumulation and export.

The permanent population is the size of the population, 
permanent residents at the time of the census in
this territory, including those temporarily absent. In the inter-census period, a current estimate of the permanent
population is made based on the census data and taking into account information from the current registration of demographic events. .
8-1-1-1.data_sources: Data collection, processing and calculation are carried out by the National Statistical Committee.
8-1-1-1.data_collection: The calculated indicator uses data from industry statistics, the State Budget, and the Balance of Payments. Frequency: quarterly, annual.
8-1-1-1.comments_limitations:
GDP per capita is one of the most important characteristics that determine the level of economic development of a state, as it allows assessing the economic development of countries based on population size.
An increase in this indicator may indicate an increase in the standard of living of the population, and therefore is a socially significant indicator. 
The growth of value-added production is the basic factor determining the state of functioning of the economy. By allocating the total volume of production to each unit of the population, it is possible to measure the degree of impact on the development of the growth rate of production, taking into account an individual. The indicator, in fact, can be considered as a summary indicator of socio-economic development.
8-1-1-1.quality_assurance: Logical and arithmetic control of the reporting data is carried out.
8-1-1-1.data_availability_gaps: Dynamic series have been available since 2006. The data is published in various publications of the National Statistical Committee, posted on the NSC website.

16-6-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
16-6-1.indicator_name: Primary government expenditures as a proportion of original approved budget, by sector (or by budget codes or similar)
16-6-1.graph_title: Primary government expenditures as a proportion of original approved budget, by sector (or by budget codes or similar)
16-6-1.goal_name: Goal 16. Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels
16-6-1.target_name: 16.6.  Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels
16-6-1.indicator_name1: 16.6.1. Primary government expenditures as a proportion of original approved budget, by sector (or by budget codes or similar)
16-6-1.organization_name: Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic (Budget Policy Department)
16-6-1.definitions: Primary government expenditures as a proportion of original approved budget
16-6-1.concepts: State budget expenditures include all non-recoverable payments, whether they are reimbursable (i.e. paid in exchange for something) or not, and the purpose - operational activities or of non-financial assets procurement. Expenditures cover the following areas: public services funding related to economic activities (industry, agriculture, construction, communications, etc. ); socio-cultural activities financing (education, recreation, culture and religion, health care, social protection, housing and utilities); general public services, defence, public order and security, environmental protection, non-financial assets procurement, etc.
16-6-1.rationale_interpretation: The indicator attempts to capture the reliability of government budgets: do governments spend what they intend to and do they collect what they set out to collect.
16-6-1.data_sources:
Data on public expenditures - data of the Central Treasury of the Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic based on reports on implementation of the state, national and local budgets. 
Law on the national budget for releavnt years.
16-6-1.data_collection: Annual reports of the Central Committee of the MoF on implementation of the state, national and local budgets. Law on the national budget for relevant years.
16-6-1.computation_methods: Primary government expenditures as a proportion of original approved budget disaggregated by sectors (in percentage terms).
16-6-1.comments_limitations:
The Law on the Nationa Budget is a source for the approved budget. 
Reports on budget implementation  serve as sources for actual expenditures
16-6-1.data_availability_gaps: Available at the MF KR website
16-6-1.disaggregation: It is an aggregate indicator at the national level
16-6-1.international_comparability: The indicator is comparable in percentage terms
