(Economic Statistics and National Accounts Division)
9-2-1.definitions: Manufacturing value added (MVA) as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) is a ratio between MVA and GDP in the country.
9-2-1.concepts:
Gross value added is calculated as difference between output of goods and services and intermediate consumption. The term «gross» indicates that indicator includes the value of fixed capital used in the production process. MVA is the key indicator of national accounts, describing the state and development of Kyrgyz industry over a certain period. It reflects the value of goods and services produced in manufacturing for final consumption, accumulation and exports.
De-facto population is population actually present in the country at the time of registration, regardless of the place of residence
Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is key indicator of national accounts, describing the state and development of the economy and trends in economic growth of the Kyrgyz Republic over a certain period. It reflects the value of goods and services produced in the country for final consumption, accumulation and export.
GDP per capita measures the standard of living of population and determines contributions to international organizations. 
GDP production per capita is calculated in KG soms and US dollars (at the official rate of the National Bank).
9-2-1.rationale_interpretation: MVA is a well-recognized and widely used indicator by researchers and policy makers to assess the level of industrialization of a country. The share of MVA in GDP reflects the role of manufacturing in the economy and a country’s national development in general. MVA per capita is the basic indicator of a country’s level of industrialization adjusted for the size of the economy. One of the statistical uses of MVA per capita is classifying country groups according to the stage of industrial development.
9-2-1.data_sources: National Statistical Committee collects, processes and calculates the data.
9-2-1.data_collection: Indicator calculated using sectoral statistics. Frequency:  quarterly, annual.
9-2-1.comments_limitations: Data on manufactured goods are collected and compiled according to the State Classification of Economic Activities (SCEA3/NACE2). GVA is calculated in accordance with the 2008 SNA standards.
9-2-1.quality_assurance: Logical and arithmetic control of recorded data is carried out.
9-2-1.data_availability_gaps: The indicator is new, data for calculation have been available since 1993 onwards to be calculated and posted on the NSC website.
9-2-1.international_comparability: Globally GDP per capita estimations are based on the resident population

9-3-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
9-3-1.indicator_name: Proportion of small-scale industries in total industry value added
9-3-1.graph_title: Proportion of small-scale industries in total industry value added
9-3-1.goal_name: 9: Build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation
9-3-1.target_name: 9.3 Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets
9-3-1.indicator_name1: 9.3.1.  Proportion of small-scale industries in total industry value added
9-3-1.organization_name:
National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic
(Economic Statistics and National Accounts Division)
9-3-1.definitions: Proportion of small-scale industries (up to 50 persons employed in production and up to 15 persons employed in services) gross value added to gross value added of industry.
9-3-1.concepts:
A small-scale industry is an economic entity, regardless of organizational and legal form of business, engaged in entrepreneurial (commercial) activities and employing up to 50 persons in production and up to 15 persons in service sector.
Gross value added is calculated as difference between output of goods and services and intermediate consumption. The term «gross» indicates that indicator includes the value of fixed capital used in the production process.
9-3-1.rationale_interpretation:
Small-scale industry statistics examine the quantitative aspects of operations and development of small business entities in relationship to quality. Small-industry statistics collect and process statistical indicators to analyze financial and economic activities of small business entities of all types of activities, including small industrial enterprises, macro-economic analysis and system of national accounts. A small-scale industry is one of the key elements of the market structure. Establishing small enterprises is a prerequisite for competitive environment, job creation and bringing in new goods and services. Small enterprises are better suited than large and medium-sized enterprises to respond quickly to market changes diversify production and innovate. Development of statistical methodology requires a clear identification of economic entities.
Small-scale industry entities are private and legal persons registered in accordance with procedures established by law and exercising at their own risk and under their property liability activities not prohibited by law, irrespective of their organizational and legal forms and forms of ownership.
9-3-1.data_sources: National Statistical Committee collects, processes and calculates the data.
9-3-1.data_collection: Indicator calculated using sectoral statistics. Frequency:  quarterly, annual.
9-3-1.comments_limitations: The definition of size class in many countries is tied up with the legal and policy framework of the country. It has implications on registration procedure, taxation and different waivers aimed to promote “small-scale industries”. The main limitation of existing national data is varying size classes by country indicating that data are obtained from different target populations. Data of one country are not comparable to another.
9-3-1.quality_assurance: Logical and arithmetic control of recorded data is carried out.

3-9-1-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
3-9-1-1.indicator_name: Mortality from the toxic effect of carbon monoxide per 100 000 population
3-9-1-1.graph_title: Mortality from the toxic effect of carbon monoxide per 100 000 population
3-9-1-1.goal_name: Goal 3 Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-9-1-1.target_name: 3.9 By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination
3-9-1-1.indicator_name1: 3.9.1.1 Mortality from the toxic effect of carbon monoxide per 100 000 population
3-9-1-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Department of Demographic Statistics)
3-9-1-1.definitions: The death rate associated with carbon monoxide poisoning resulting from inhaling dangerous concentrations of carbon monoxide.
3-9-1-1.concepts:
Population mortality is the process of generation extinction, one of the two main subprocesses of population reproduction. 
Causes of death are diseases, pathological conditions, or injuries that led to or contributed to death, as well as the circumstances of an accident or act of violence that caused a fatal injury. 
Causes of death have been coded since 2000 based on the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Causes of Death, 10th Revision of the World Health Organization (ICD-10).
3-9-1-1.rationale_interpretation:
The analysis of this indicator makes it possible to assess the effectiveness of preventive measures to prevent fires and other cases in which carbon monoxide poisoning may occur.
The level of this indicator is also used to assess
the social well-being of the population.
3-9-1-1.data_sources: The source of information about the causes of death is the entries in medical death certificates drawn up by a doctor or secondary medical staff regarding illness, accident, murder, suicide and other external influences that caused death. These documents, together with the death certificates, are sent to the state statistical authorities for development.
3-9-1-1.data_collection: Information on deaths is obtained on the basis of the annual statistical development of the data contained in the death records compiled by the civil registry offices.  Aggregated data is collected and processed by the regional statistical offices and the NSC of the Kyrgyz Republic.
3-9-1-1.computation_methods: The ratio of the number of deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning to the average annual permanent population according to current estimates. Calculated per 100,000 population.
3-9-1-1.comments_limitations: Know the rules for encoding the initial cause of death and definitions set out in the classifier, International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems 10th Revision (ICD-10). In case of difficulty with the correctness of the diagnosis, contact the staff of the E-Health Center of the Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic in order to establish a definitive diagnosis.
3-9-1-1.quality_assurance: Logical and arithmetic control of the reporting data is carried out. The procedure for verifying the correctness of data in death records is carried out through logical control embedded in the data entry and development software. Correction of the affixed cause of death codes to match the diagnoses recorded in the death certificate, according to ICD-10. Analysis of output tables by causes of death.
3-9-1-1.disaggregation: Data is disaggregated by territory (republic, region, district), and by gender.
3-9-1-1.international_comparability: The national definition of the indicator used in statistics corresponds to its international definition. The coding and development of data on deaths due to causes of death are carried out by state statistical authorities on the basis of the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Causes of Death, 10th revision (ICD-10) The World Health Organization (WHO), since the 2000 report. By agreement with the NSC, the mortality database is transferred to the Center for Electronic Health of the Kyrgyz Republic under the Ministry of Health: form C52 "Mortality by causes of death" – annually, in June of the year following the reporting year.
3-9-1-1.references_documentation:
Links to the NPA and methodology: http://www.stat.kg/ru/about/pravovye-osnovy-organov-gosudarstvennoj-statistiki /; https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata ; http://www.stat.kg/ru/statistics/download/methodology/68 /.
National SDG Reporting Platform of the Kyrgyz Republic: https://sustainabledevelopment-kyrgyzstan .github.io

9-3-2.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
9-3-2.indicator_name: Proportion of small-scale industries with a loan or line of credit
9-3-2.graph_title: Proportion of small-scale industries with a loan or line of credit
9-3-2.nan:
Метаданные на сайте ООН: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/
Методология показателей доступна на сайте НСК КР: www.stat.kg
9-3-2.goal_name: 9. Build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation
9-3-2.target_name: 9.3 Increase the access of small-scale industrial and other enterprises, in particular in developing countries, to financial services, including affordable credit, and their integration into value chains and markets
9-3-2.indicator_name1: 9.3.2 Proportion of small-scale industries with a loan or line of credit
9-3-2.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic  (Department of Finance and Price Statistics)
9-3-2.definitions: The number of "small enterprises" with an active credit line or loan from a financial institution in the reporting year as a percentage of the total number of such enterprises.
9-3-2.concepts: An enterprise as an economic category is economic agents or persons operating in a market economy engaged in the production and (or) sale of goods and market services in order to generate profit and maximize it. The list of employees includes all employees employed under an employment contract (contract) for permanent, temporary or seasonal work for a period of one day or more, as well as employed owners of enterprises who received wages in this enterprise. In addition, employees working under a civil law contract are shown here, if these employees are not on the lists of other enterprises. The average number of employees per year is determined by summing the average monthly number of employees for all months of the reporting year and dividing the amount received by 12. A loan is a financial instrument that is created when a creditor provides funds directly to a debtor and receives a non-reviewable document as proof of an asset. These are overdrafts, mortgages, loans to finance trade loans and advances, repurchase agreements, financial assets and liabilities created as a result of finance leases, as well as claims or obligations to the IMF in the form of loans. Credit lines and loan commitments provide a guarantee that unused funds will be available in the future, but no financial obligations/assets exist until such funds are actually provided.
9-3-2.rationale_interpretation: To improve the skills of workers and production technologies, small industrial enterprises need financial support in the form of preferential loans, loans, etc. This indicator shows how widely financial institutions serve "small-scale industries" (small enterprises, including industrial ones). Together with the SDG indicator 9.3.1, this indicator reflects the main message of target 9.3, which helps to increase the access of "small enterprises" to financial services.
9-3-2.data_sources: Official statistical reporting forms. Commercial small enterprises with employees from 1 to 9 people (inclusive) - form No. 1-FHD-Micro (year) “Report on the main performance indicators of a small enterprise”, the rest of the enterprises - form No. 6-f (year) “Report on the main mutual settlements of enterprises (organizations)”
9-3-2.data_collection: A continuous annual statistical observation, the unit of which is an enterprise with an independent balance sheet and the status of a legal entity belonging to the sector of non-financial corporations (the real sector of the economy). For calculations, enterprises with an average annual payroll of up to 20 people (from 0 to 19 people inclusive) are cut off from the entire set of reported enterprises in the real sector of the economy.
9-3-2.computation_methods: For all types of economic activity: The number of small enterprises with an active credit line or loan / The total number of small enterprises * 100. By enterprises with the type of economic activity industry (with GCED version 3 codes: B + C + D + E): The number of small industrial enterprises with an active credit line or loan / The total number of small industrial enterprises * 100.
9-3-2.comments_limitations: When calculating the share, the debt indicator (the amount of the outstanding balance) on borrowed funds, loans and borrowings as of the end of the reporting year was used. In order to obtain internationally comparable data, at the suggestion of UNIDO, the National Statistical Committee compiled data on the size class of “small-scale industries” employing less than 20 people.
9-3-2.data_availability_gaps: Data on the indicator has been available on an annual basis since 2008.
9-3-2.disaggregation: The data on the indicator are presented for the Kyrgyz Republic as a whole, including industrial enterprises.

17-11-1-a.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
17-11-1-a.indicator_name: Imports of ICT goods as a percentage of total imports of goods
17-11-1-a.graph_title: Imports of ICT goods as a percentage of total imports of goods
17-11-1-a.nan: Показатели связанные с ИКТ, которые были представлены ОЭСР и рекомендованы Статистической комиссией ООН. Товары ИКТ — это товары, обеспечивающие внедрение информационно-коммуникационных технологий. Список товаров ИКТ разработан ОЭСР и ЮНКТАД на основе определения товаров ИКТ в Руководстве ОЭСР по измерению информационного общества (2011 года) и одобрен Статистической комиссией ООН.
17-11-1-a.goal_name: 17. Strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development
17-11-1-a.target_name: 17.11 Significantly increase the exports of developing countries, in particular with a view to doubling the least developed countries’ share of global exports by 2020
17-11-1-a.indicator_name1: 17.11.1.a Imports of ICT goods as a percentage of total imports of goods
17-11-1-a.organization_name:
National Statistical Committee
Department of Foreign Trade Statistics of the Kyrgyz Republic
17-11-1-a.concepts: Data on statistics on foreign and mutual trade, both in general and on ICT goods, are compiled by processing information contained in Declarations on Goods (customs statistics) and data from state statistical observations and surveys on foreign and mutual trade (forms of state statistical reporting).
17-11-1-a.rationale_interpretation: Данные по статистике внешней и взаимной торговли как в целом, так и по товарам ИКТ составляются путем обработки информации, содержащейся в Декларациях на товары (таможенная статистика) и данных государственных статистических наблюдений и обследований по внешней и взаимной торговле (формы государственной статистические отчетности).
17-11-1-a.data_sources: The sources of information are statistics on foreign and mutual trade in goods of the Kyrgyz Republic. The initial data is available from the database on foreign and mutual trade in goods, developed by the National Statistical Committee. The data is available on a regular basis (monthly and annual figures).
17-11-1-a.data_collection: Data on statistics on foreign and mutual trade, both in general and on ICT goods, are compiled by processing information contained in Declarations on Goods (customs statistics) and data from state statistical observations and surveys on foreign and mutual trade (forms of state statistical reporting).
17-11-1-a.computation_methods: The indicators are calculated by dividing the cost of importing or exporting goods classified as ICT goods (the amount of imports or exports of commodity items according to the list of compliance with the EAEU HS codes) by the total cost of importing or exporting goods. The result is multiplied by 100 to express it as a percentage.
17-11-1-a.comments_limitations: ICT goods are defined according to the OECD classification of ICT goods, which is based on the classification of the Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System of the World Customs Organization, consistent in codes with the Unified Commodity Nomenclature for Foreign Economic Activity of the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU) at the level of 6 characters in accordance with the Recommendation of the Board of the Eurasian Economic Commission dated 03.12.2018 No. 27
17-11-1-a.quality_assurance: Logical and arithmetic control of the reporting data, analysis of the output tables is carried out. The procedure for verifying the correctness of data on the import and export of ICT goods as a percentage of the total volume of imports and exports of goods is carried out through logical control embedded in the data entry and development software.
17-11-1-a.definitions:
Import of goods – import into the territory of the Kyrgyz Republic
from the territory of another state of goods that are added
to the reserves of material resources of the republic;
ICT products are products that ensure the implementation of information and communication technologies. 
The import of ICT goods as a percentage of the total volume of imports of goods is the annual value of imports of ICT goods divided by the total value of imports of goods (as a percentage).
17-11-1-a.international_comparability: ICT-related indicators, which were presented by the OECD and recommended by the UN Statistical Commission. ICT products are products that ensure the implementation of information and communication technologies. The list of ICT products was developed by the OECD and UNCTAD based on the definition of ICT products in the OECD Guidelines on Measuring the Information Society (2011) and approved by the UN Statistical Commission.

6-1-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
6-1-1.indicator_name: Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services
6-1-1.graph_title: Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services
6-1-1.goal_name: 6: Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all
6-1-1.target_name: 6.1. By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all
6-1-1.indicator_name1: 6.1.1. Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services
6-1-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Department of Household Statistics)
6-1-1.definitions: Proportion of population using safely managed drinking water services is currently being measured by the proportion of population using an improved basic drinking water source which is located on premises and available when needed and free of faecal (and priority chemical) contamination. ‘Improved’ source defined the same as used for MDG monitoring i.e. piped water into dwelling, yard or plot; public taps or standpipes; boreholes or tubewells; protected dug wells; protected springs and rainwater.
6-1-1.concepts:
Improved drinking water sources include the following: piped water into dwelling, yard or plot; public taps or standpipes; boreholes or tubewells; protected dug wells; protected springs and rainwater. Packaged drinking water is considered improved if households use an improved water source for other domestic purposes. A water source is considered to be ‘located on premises’ if the point of collection is within the dwelling, yard, or plot. ‘Available when needed’: households are able to access sufficient quantities of water when needed.
‘Free from faecal and priority chemical contamination’: water complies with relevant national or local standards. In the absence of such standards, reference is made to the WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality
(http://www.who.int/water_sanitation_health/dwq/guidelines/en/).
6-1-1.rationale_interpretation:
MDG target 7C called for ‘sustainable access’ to ‘safe drinking water’. At the start of the MDG period, there was a complete lack of nationally representative data about drinking water safety in developing countries, and such data were not collected through household surveys or censuses. The JMP developed the concept of ‘improved’ water sources, which was used as a proxy for ‘safe water’, as such sources are likely to be protected against faecal contamination, and this metric has been used since 2000 to track progress towards the MDG target. International consultations since 2011 have established consensus on the need to build on and address the shortcomings of this indicator; specifically, to address normative criteria of the human right to water including accessibility, availability and quality.
The above consultation concluded that JMP should go beyond the basic level of access and address safe management of drinking water services, including dimensions of accessibility, availability and quality. The proposed indicator of ‘safely managed drinking water services’ is designed to address this.
6-1-1.data_sources: Integrated Household Budget and Labour Force Sample Survey
6-1-1.data_collection: Data collected through quarterly questionnaire №1 «Household control card» and annual questionnaire №2 «Socio-demographic characteristics of household residents», section 4 «Knowledge and skills of household members» using a cluster sample built on the latest available Census data and up-to-date housing lists. The IHBLFSS polls use computer assisted personal interviews (ComputerAssisted Personal Interview, CAPI).
6-1-1.computation_methods: The indicator is calculated by dividing the total number of persons living in households with improved basic drinking water sources by the total population. All calculations are done using weighted factors.
6-1-1.comments_limitations: Data on availability and safety of drinking water is increasingly available through a combination of household surveys and administrative sources including regulators, but definitions have yet to be standardized. Data on faecal and chemical contamination, drawn from household surveys and regulatory databases, will not cover all countries immediately. However, sufficient data exist to make global and regional estimates of safely managed drinking water services.
6-1-1.disaggregation: Indicator is disaggregated by region (geographical and urban / rural location).
6-1-1.international_comparability:
National household surveys measure the indicator directly, which creates discrepancies with the international methodology. The WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme for Water Supply and Sanitation (JMP) estimates access to basic services for each country, separately in urban and rural areas, by fitting a regression line to a series of data points from household surveys and censuses. This approach was used to report on use of ‘improved water’ sources for MDG monitoring. The JMP is evaluating the use of alternative statistical estimation methods as more data become available. The accompanying Methodological Note describes in more detail how data on availability and quality from different sources, can be combined with data on use of different types of supplies, as recorded in the current JMP database to compute the proposed indicator. http://www.wssinfo.org/fileadmin/user_upload/resources/Methodological-note-on-monitoring-SDG-targets-for-WASH-and-wastewater_WHO-UNICEF_8October2015_Final.pdf.  
WHO is required by World Health Assembly resolution to consult on all WHO statistics, and seek feedback from countries on data about countries and territories. Before publishing, all JMP estimates undergo rigorous country consultations facilitated by WHO and UNICEF country offices. Often these consultations give rise to in-country visits, and meetings about data reconciliations. JMP has been engaged with more than fifty countries over the last 10 years in explaining JMP estimates, and reasons for discrepancies if any. JMP has also developed an online tool to facilitate future data validation and expanded its online capabilities so that these reconciliations could be done in much more interactive and real time manner, reducing cost of reconciliations missions.

2-c-1-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
2-c-1-1.indicator_name: Consumer price index for food products
2-c-1-1.graph_title: Consumer price index for food products
2-c-1-1.measurement_units: Percentage compared to December of the previous year
2-c-1-1.goal_name: 2: End hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture.
2-c-1-1.target_name: 2.с Adopt measures to ensure the proper functioning of food commodity markets and their derivatives and facilitate timely access to market information, including on food reserves, in order to help limit extreme food price volatility
2-c-1-1.indicator_name1: 2.c.1.1 Consumer price index for food products in the Kyrgyz Republic and by regions
2-c-1-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Price Statistics Department)
2-c-1-1.definitions: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) reflects changes in the general price level for goods and services purchased by the population for non-productive consumption over time. The CPI measures the ratio of the value of a fixed set of goods and services at current period prices to its value at prices of the previous (base) period.This indicator is one of the main inflation measures, based on the comparison of the prices of a basket of key consumer goods weighted according to their share in total consumption.
2-c-1-1.concepts:
The Price Index is a relative indicator expressed as a coefficient or percentage that characterizes price changes over time (dynamic index) or across regions (spatial index).

Individual price index is the ratio of the price of a particular good or service in the reporting period to its price in the base period.

Group price index is the weighted average of all individual price indices for a specific group or subgroup of goods and services.

Overall price index is the weighted average of all group indices and reflects the general change in prices for the selected goods or services.
A fixed consumer basket is a unified list of goods and paid services most frequently consumed by the population, selected uniformly for all regions of the Kyrgyz Republic.
A representative good/service is defined as a set of distinguishing characteristics of a product or service that are homogeneous in terms of consumer purpose.
A price (tariff) is the monetary expression of the value of a good or service.
Consumer (retail) price (tariff) is the actual price or tariff at which goods and services are sold to the population at retail, including through shops, markets, stalls, and kiosks. It includes VAT, excise tax, sales tax, other indirect taxes, and distribution network costs.
Comparable price (tariff) refers to the price for a product or service in the reporting and base periods for the same assortment and quality characteristics, collected from selected baseline enterprises.
2-c-1-1.rationale_interpretation: The CPI is a key indicator reflecting inflationary processes in the country and is used for fiscal and monetary policy implementation, economic price analysis and forecasting, adjustment of minimum social guarantees for the population, and in legal dispute resolutions.
2-c-1-1.data_collection: Sample-based statistical survey. Prices are registered by official statisticians using smartphones or tablets. Data are transmitted online to the NSC central server.
2-c-1-1.computation_methods: The statistical survey of consumer prices and tariffs is conducted on a sample basis. Price registration is carried out by specialists of the state statistical bodies. Prices are recorded using smartphones/tablets, and the information is transmitted online to the server of the NSC.
2-c-1-1.comments_limitations: The indicator reflects events that have occurred.
2-c-1-1.quality_assurance: The registration of comparable prices is carried out.
2-c-1-1.data_availability_gaps: Data are available on the official NSC website: www.stat.gov.kg
2-c-1-1.disaggregation: Data are presented for the Kyrgyz Republic, its regions, and 18 cities.
2-c-1-1.references_documentation:
Methodological documentation:
http://www.stat.kg/ru/metodologicheskie-polozheniya-po-statistike/ceny-i-tarify/  

Kyrgyz Republic SDG National Reporting Platform:
https://sustainabledevelopment-kyrgyzstan.github.io
2-c-1-1.data_sources:
Average comparable prices
Weights for aggregation of indices

1-2-1-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
1-2-1-1.indicator_name: Proportion of employed population living below the official poverty line
1-2-1-1.graph_title: Proportion of employed population living below the official poverty line
1-2-1-1.goal_name: 1. End poverty in all its forms everywhere
1-2-1-1.target_name: 1.2: By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions
1-2-1-1.indicator_name1: 1.2.1.1 Poverty rate among the employed population according to the national poverty line
1-2-1-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic 1.Labour and Employment Statistics Division 2.Department of Household Statistics
1-2-1-1.contact_email:
G. Zh. Jailobaeva: jailobaeva@stat.kg
Kalymbetova Yryskan: yryskan.kalymbetova@gmail.com
1-2-1-1.definitions: Poverty rate among employed population is a proportion of employed population in classified as poor households
1-2-1-1.concepts:
Employed population (see the link) 
Poverty line is the minimum level of income deemed adequate to satisfy minimum human needs.
Consumption expenditures of the household are monetary expenditures on non-food consumer goods and services, and the value of food consumption.
1-2-1-1.rationale_interpretation: Poverty indicator among the employed population is designed for the purpose of the government policy development to ensure full and productive employment for all, including women and youth
1-2-1-1.data_sources: Integrated Sample Household Budget and Labour Force Survey (IHS).
1-2-1-1.data_collection:
Interviewers conduct the survey making direct visits to households and completing IHS questionnaires approved by the Kyrgyz Republic National Statistical Committee Resolution. Employment and Unemployment Module is filled for all persons in the household aged 15 years and older.  The IHS is based on personal interviews using tablet computers (ComputerAssisted Personal Interview, CAPI).
The data are collected on a quarterly basis, and the indicator is developed based on the end-of-year results.
1-2-1-1.computation_methods:
Poverty rate among the employed population is calculated based on two standards: ILO methodology is used for employed population; poverty measure is used for poor population.
Given that these two surveys are integrated in Kyrgyzstan, and that employment and living standards questionnaires are filled out in the same households, this indicator is calculated merging the data from both data sets.
1-2-1-1.comments_limitations: The indicator is calculated for the employed population aged 15 years and older.
1-2-1-1.quality_assurance: The raw data are quality-tested before being used for further analysis.
1-2-1-1.data_availability_gaps: A comparable time series based on a single methodology is available since 2000.
1-2-1-1.disaggregation: National and subnational level, by location, sex and age groups
1-2-1-1.international_comparability: The poverty among the employed population is calculated using the national poverty line and is not comparable with other countries.

2-2-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
2-2-1.indicator_name: Prevalence of stunting (height for age <-2 standard deviation from the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards) among children under 5 years of age
2-2-1.graph_title: Распространенность задержки роста среди детей в возрасте до пяти лет (среднеквадратичное отклонение от медианного показателя роста к возрасту ребенка в соответствии с нормами роста детей, установленными Всемирной организацией здравоохранения <-2)
2-2-1.goal_name: 2: End hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture
2-2-1.target_name: 2.2: By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons
2-2-1.indicator_name1: 2.2.1: Prevalence of stunting (height for age <-2 standard deviation from the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards) among children under 5 years of age
2-2-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz republic (Department of Household Statistics) under the UNICEF MICS global programme
2-2-1.definitions: Prevalence of stunting (height-for-age <-2 standard deviation from the median of the World Health Organization (WHO) Child Growth Standards) among children under 5 years of age.
2-2-1.concepts: For a well-nourished population, there is a reference distribution of height and weight for children under 5. The reference population used in this report is based on WHO Child Growth Standards 89. The malnutrition of population can be measured by comparing children with this reference population. Each of three indicators - weight for age, height for age and weight for growth - can be expressed in units of standard deviation (z-score) based on the reference population median.
2-2-1.rationale_interpretation: Child growth is an internationally accepted outcome reflecting child nutritional status. Child stunting refers to a child who is too short for his or her age and is the result of chronic or recurrent malnutrition. Stunting is a contributing risk factor to child mortality and is also a marker of inequalities in human development. Stunted children fail to reach their physical and cognitive potential. Child stunting is one of the World Health Assembly nutrition target indicators.
2-2-1.data_sources: «On the situation of children and women» Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey conducted in the Kyrgyz Republic in accordance with the rounds of MICS international household survey.
2-2-1.data_collection: Sample Household Survey «On the situation of children and women», includes “Anthropometric measurements of children under 5” module.
2-2-1.computation_methods:
Household survey collects anthropometric measurements at the individual level.
Survey estimates are obtained using a standardized methodology applying WHO Child Growth Standards, as described in another source (WHO Anthro/Anthro software manual). Global and regional estimates are based on the methodology outlined in “Joint Child Malnutrition Estimates-Levels and Trends (UNICEF/WHO / WB-2012)”.
2-2-1.comments_limitations: Only data that have passed data quality control is used for estimates. Any technical errors, such as measurement errors, recording errors are excluded from calculations at all levels: country, regional and global.
2-2-1.quality_assurance: Data quality control ensured at all survey stages: toolset design, sampling, training, interview techniques, data control with weekly production of data quality tables, calculation of weights, calculation of indicators, report preparation. Experts from UNICEF country, regional and headquarters offices conducted the audit. When calculating the indicator no imputation of missing values is applied.
2-2-1.data_availability_gaps: Availability of country assessments in accordance with the UNICEF MICS international rounds.
2-2-1.disaggregation: Estimates refer to the age group of children under 5 years, sexes combined and disaggregated at national and sub national level by area, sex, age groups, wealth quintile, mothers' education.
2-2-1.international_comparability: Data are collected and calculated in accordance with international standards and are comparable across countries.

10-b-1-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
10-b-1-1.indicator_name: Total resource flows for development, by donor and sector
10-b-1-1.graph_title: Total resource flows for development, by donor and sector

11-7-1-a.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
11-7-1-a.indicator_name: Area of green spaces and plantations in settlements per 1,000 inhabitants
11-7-1-a.graph_title: Area of green spaces and plantations in settlements per 1,000 inhabitants (hectares)
11-7-1-a.goal_name: 11. Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable
11-7-1-a.target_name: 11.7 By 2030, provide universal access to safe, inclusive and accessible, green and public spaces, in particular for women and children, older persons and persons with disabilities
11-7-1-a.indicator_name1: 11.7.1.a Green space and plantation area in urban settlements per 1,000 population per hectare
11-7-1-a.organization_name: Department of Digital Development and Sustainable Development Statistics
11-7-1-a.definitions: The area of green spaces in settlements per capita reflects the results of measures for greening settlements aimed at improving the ecological state of the environment and landscaping the territory.
11-7-1-a.rationale_interpretation: Green spaces are of great importance from a sanitary, hygienic and social point of view. The most important hygienic feature of green spaces is expressed in the regulation of thermal and radiation conditions, in the creation of a microclimate that provides comfortable environmental conditions. Equally important is the fact that green spaces are a powerful factor in protecting populated areas from dust, gases, wind and noise. In addition, they have a beneficial effect on the central nervous system of a person through the senses, improving his well-being.
11-7-1-a.data_sources: Data collection is carried out by the NSC on the basis of the state statistical reporting form No. 1 - Improvement "Report on the improvement and sanitary cleaning of cities and settlements" from the combines of municipal enterprises, organizations engaged in the improvement of cities and settlements, population data.
11-7-1-a.data_collection: The total area of all green spaces includes the area of all green areas and plantings listed at the end of the year. These are: specially planted or natural forests, green and protective zones; forest parks, citywide (village-wide) and regional parks of culture and recreation, children's parks, gardens and parks, boulevards, squares; plantings in residential areas, indoor landscaping; green spaces of cemeteries, etc. types of special-purpose landscaping and restricted-use plantings located on the territory of: educational institutions, healthcare institutions, kindergartens and nurseries, public buildings, sports complexes, industrial enterprises, etc.; flower beds and lawns located along streets, squares, embankments, etc. Tree planting in holes (along streets, driveways, and embankments) is not included in the total area of all green areas and plantings.
11-7-1-a.computation_methods: The area of green spaces and massifs in populated areas per 1000 people per 1 ha = The area of green spaces and massifs in populated areas/population *1000
11-7-1-a.comments_limitations: The norm of landscaping is considered to be 25 hectares of green spaces per person.
11-7-1-a.data_availability_gaps: Annual Statistical Collection "Environment in the Kyrgyz Republic)
11-7-1-a.references_documentation: National SDG Reporting Platform: https://sustainabledevelopment-kyrgyzstan.github.io The official website of the NSC KR: http://www.stat.kg/ru/statistics/turizm-otdyh-ohrana-okruzhayushej-sredy/

3-b-2.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
3-b-2.indicator_name: Total net official development assistance to medical research and basic health sectors
3-b-2.graph_title: Total net official development assistance to medical research and basic health sectors
3-b-2.measurement_units: В млн постоянных долл. США 2023 года
3-b-2.goal_name: 3. Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-b-2.target_name: 3.b Support the research and development of vaccines and medicines for the communicable and non-communicable diseases that primarily affect developing countries, provide access to affordable essential medicines and vaccines, in accordance with the Doha Declaration on the TRIPS Agreement and Public Health, which affirms the right of developing countries to use to the full the provisions in the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights regarding flexibilities to protect public health, and, in particular, provide access to medicines for all
3-b-2.indicator_name1: 3.b.2 Total net official development assistance to the medical research and basic health sectors
3-b-2.organization_name:
Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic, 
Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic
3-b-2.contact_name: Kenjebaeva Chinara Sharshenovna – Acting Head of the International Cooperation Department, MoF KR
3-b-2.definitions: Total official development assistance (hereinafter ODA) to the medical research and basic health sectors is currently measured as gross disbursements of total ODA from all donors to medical research and minimum health support.
3-b-2.concepts:
The DAC defines ODA as “those flows to countries and territories on the DAC List of ODA Recipients and to multilateral institutions which are
i) provided by official agencies, including state and local governments, or by their executive agencies; and
ii) each transaction is administered with the promotion of the economic development and welfare of developing countries as its main objective
3-b-2.rationale_interpretation: Total ODA flows to developing countries quantify the public effort that donors provide to developing countries for medical research and basic health.
3-b-2.data_collection: Reporting on public investment projects (monthly) spending, progress reporting on public investment projects (quarterly)
3-b-2.computation_methods: The sum of ODA flows from all donors to developing countries for medical research and basic health.
3-b-2.quality_assurance: DAC statistics are standardized on a calendar year basis for all donors and may differ from fiscal year data available in budget documents for some countries.
3-b-2.data_availability_gaps: On a donor basis, for all DAC countries and for many non-DAC suppliers (bilateral and multilateral) that report to DAC at the sectoral level. On a recipient basis for all developing countries eligible for ODA. Data are reported on an annual basis.
3-b-2.disaggregation: This indicator can be disaggregated by donor, recipient country, type of finance, type of aid, health subsector, etc.

11-6-1-2.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
11-6-1-2.indicator_name: Household disposal of municipal solid waste, by type
11-6-1-2.graph_title: Household disposal of municipal solid waste, by type
11-6-1-2.goal_name: 11. Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable
11-6-1-2.target_name: 11.6 By 2030, reduce the adverse per capita environmental impact of cities, including by paying special attention to air quality and municipal and other waste management
11-6-1-2.indicator_name1: 11.6.1.2 Household disposal of municipal solid waste, by type
11-6-1-2.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Department of Household Statistics)
11-6-1-2.concepts:
"The ways in which households dispose of their garbage includes both organized disposal systems and informal/unsafe methods.

Types of disposal:
A garbage chute is a centralized garbage disposal system inside a building (usually in apartment buildings).

Truck/container collection is the regular disposal of waste by public or private services.

Dumping in garbage heaps is the disposal of waste in unauthorized places (on vacant lots, roadsides, etc.).

Incineration is the self–incineration of waste, often outdoors.

Burying is the independent disposal of waste in the soil, usually near the house.
"
11-6-1-2.rationale_interpretation: The indicator of ways to get rid of waste produced indicates the environmental impact on atmospheric, water and land resources. At the same time, the ways to get rid of waste directly depend on access to services provided by public utilities. A balanced waste management program should aim to minimize the amount of waste, as well as promote proper waste disposal and recycling.
11-6-1-2.data_sources: Integrated survey of household budgets and labor force, National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz
11-6-1-2.data_collection:
Republic "Data collection is carried out by interviewing homes as part of a sample survey of households conducted in all regions of the republic on a quarterly basis.
The object of statistical observation is the composition and housing conditions of households. The unit of observation is households.
Conducting a sample integrated survey of household budgets and the workforce is regulated by the Decree of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic "On statistics of sample household surveys" dated January 17, 2004 No. 25 and the Program of Statistical Work. The indicator is monitored annually.
"
11-6-1-2.computation_methods: It is calculated by the ratio of the number of households using various methods of disposal of household waste to the total number of households.
11-6-1-2.quality_assurance: The quality of the indicator is guaranteed by the use of a representative sample in the IODH, compliance with the terms and conditions of the survey, as well as multi-stage control, including checking the questionnaires for completeness and logical consistency.
11-6-1-2.data_availability_gaps: 1) Annual statistical Compendium of the state of the environment in the Kyrgyz Republic; 2) Annual Compendium of the Standard of Living of the population

10-1-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
10-1-1.indicator_name: Growth rates of household expenditure or income per capita among the bottom 40 per cent of the population and the total population
10-1-1.graph_title: Темпы роста доходов домохозяйств на душу населения среди наименее обеспеченных 40 процентов населения и среди населения в целом
10-1-1.goal_name: Goal 10. Reduce inequality within and among countries
10-1-1.target_name: 10.1. By 2030, progressively achieve and sustain the above national average income growth among the poorest 40 per cent of the population
10-1-1.indicator_name1: 10.1.1. Growth rate of household expenditure or per capita income among the poorest 40 per cent of the population and the population in general
10-1-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Department of Household Statistics)
10-1-1.definitions:
The growth rate in the welfare aggregate of bottom 40% is computed as the annualized average growth rate in per capita real consumption or income of the bottom 40% of the income distribution in a country from household surveys over a roughly 5-year period. The national average growth rate in the welfare
aggregate is computed as the annualized average growth rate in per capita real consumption or income of the total population in a country from household surveys over a roughly 5-year period.
10-1-1.concepts: Promoting shared prosperity is defined as fostering income growth of the bottom 40 percent of the welfare distribution in every country and is measured by calculating the annualized growth of mean per capita real income or consumption of the bottom 40 percent. The choice of the bottom 40 percent as the target population is one of practical compromise. The bottom 40 percent differs across countries depending on the welfare distribution, and it can change over time within a country. Because boosting shared prosperity is a country-specific goal, there is no numerical target defined globally.
10-1-1.rationale_interpretation:
Improvements in shared prosperity require both a growing economy and a consideration of equity. Shared prosperity explicitly recognizes that while growth is necessary for improving economic welfare in a society, progress is measured by how those gains are shared with its poorest members. Moreover, in an inclusive society it is not sufficient to raise everyone above an absolute inimum standard of living; it must ensure that economic growth increases prosperity among the poor over time.
The decision to measure shared prosperity based on income or consumption was not taken to ignore the many other dimensions of welfare. It is motivated by the need for an indicator that is easy to understand, communicate, and measure—though measurement challenges exist. Indeed, shared prosperity comprises many dimensions of well-being of the less well-off, and when analyzing shared prosperity in the context of a country, it is important to consider a wide range of indicators of welfare.
10-1-1.data_sources: National representative household surveys, including income or consumption module.
10-1-1.computation_methods: Growth rates are calculated as annualized average growth rates over a roughly five-year period.
10-1-1.comments_limitations: There are mainly two limitations of shared prosperity indicators: data availability and data quality.
10-1-1.disaggregation: No disaggregations are required for this indicator
10-1-1.international_comparability: To generate measures of shared prosperity that are reasonably comparable across countries, the World Bank Group has a standardized approach for choosing time periods, data sources, and other relevant parameters.
10-1-1.references_documentation:
SDG National Reporting Platform: https://sustainabledevelopment-kyrgyzstan.github.io 
Data are published in statistical compendiums “Employment and Unemployment”, “Women and Men in the Kyrgyz Republic”, “Kyrgyzstan in Figures”

3-3-3.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
3-3-3.goal_name: 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
3-3-3.target_name: 3.3. By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases
3-3-3.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of KR (Social Statistics Division)
3-3-3.definitions: Incidence of malaria is defined as the number of new cases of malaria per 1,000 people at risk each year.
3-3-3.concepts: Case of malaria is defined as the occurrence of malaria infection in a person whom the presence of malaria parasites in the blood has been confirmed by a diagnostic test. The population considered is the population at risk of the disease.
3-3-3.rationale_interpretation: To measure trends in malaria morbidity and to identify locations where the risk of disease is highest. With this information, programmes can respond to unusual trends, such as epidemics, and direct resources to the populations most in need. This data also serves to inform global resource allocation for malaria such as when defining eligibility criteria for Global Fund finance.
3-3-3.data_sources: The Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic submits a consolidated report with data broken down by region in the State statistical reporting form "Report on communicable, parasitic and non-communicable diseases", as well as demographic statistics.
3-3-3.data_collection: Data are collected by district, city and regional SSESD centers and Sanitary and Epidemiological Surveillance Department.
3-3-3.computation_methods:
The indicator is calculated as the ratio of newly diagnosed malaria cases to the annual average population multiplied by 100,000.
Malaria incidence (MI) is calculated by the formula:

 
MI   =  N  * 100 000 / P1 
 
where 
N – number of newly diagnosed cases recorded in given year; 
P1 – annual average population.
3-3-3.comments_limitations:
The estimated incidence can differ from the incidence reported by a Ministry of Health which can be affected by:
• the completeness of reporting: the number of reported cases can be lower than the estimated cases
if the percentage of health facilities reporting in a month is less than 100%
• the extent of malaria diagnostic testing (the number of slides examined or RDTs performed)
• the use of private health facilities which are usually not included in reporting systems.
• the indicator is estimated only where malaria transmission occurs
3-3-3.data_availability_gaps: Data have been available since 2007 onwards
3-3-3.disaggregation: Data are disaggregated by region, sex and age.
3-3-3.international_comparability: The International Classification of Diseases and Causes of Death allows studying diseases according to common principles and obtaining comparable results.

2-a-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
2-a-1.indicator_name: The agriculture orientation index for government expenditures
2-a-1.graph_title: The agriculture orientation index for government expenditures
2-a-1.goal_name: 2. End hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture
2-a-1.target_name:
2.a: Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance
agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in
particular least developed countries.
2-a-1.indicator_name1: 2.a.1: The agriculture orientation index for government expenditures
2-a-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Finance Statistics Division).
2-a-1.definitions: The Agriculture Orientation Index (AOI) for Government Expenditures is defined as the Agriculture Share of Government Expenditures, divided by the Agriculture Share of GDP, where Agriculture refers to the agriculture, forestry, fishing and hunting sector. T
2-a-1.concepts:
State budget expenditures include all non-recoverable payments, whether they are reimbursable (i.e. paid in exchange for something) or not, and for what purpose - operational activities or acquisition of non-financial assets.
Government expenditure on agriculture includes: sectoral policies and programmes, soil improvement and control of soil degradation, irrigation and water supply for agricultural use, animal health control, livestock research and training, marine or freshwater biological research, afforestation and other forestry projects, etc. Agriculture share in GDP is measured by the ratio of agricultural value added to GDP.
2-a-1.rationale_interpretation: An Agriculture Orientation Index (AOI) greater than 1 reflects a higher orientation towards the agriculture sector, which receives a higher share of government spending relative to its contribution to economic value-added. An AOI less than 1 reflects a lower orientation to agriculture, while an AOI equal to 1 reflects neutrality in a government’s orientation to the agriculture sector.
2-a-1.data_sources:
Government expenditure data - administrative data of the Central Treasury of the Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic (CT MoF KR) from reports on national, republican and local budget implementation.
Data on gross value added of agriculture and GDP (or GDP agriculture share) - Department of Economic Statistics and National Accounts of the National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic.
2-a-1.data_collection:
CT MoF KR submits reports on national, republican and local budget implementation on monthly and annual basis. 
GDP data are compiled by Department of Economic Statistics and National Accounts of the National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic in accordance with Statistical Work Programme.
2-a-1.computation_methods:
Computation Method:
AOI = (Agriculture Share of Government Expenditures) / (Agriculture Share of GDP), where
1) Agriculture Share of Government Expenditures = (Central Government Expenditures on Agriculture) /
(Total Central Government Outlays); and
2) Agriculture Share of GDP = (Agriculture Value-Added) / GDP
2-a-1.comments_limitations: Since the numerator of this data is based on administrative sources, there is no confidence interval or standard error associated with government expenditure data. For the denominator, national accounts data typically do not provide any standard error or confidence interval information.
2-a-1.data_availability_gaps: Indicator data have been annually available since 2007. The data are available on the NSC website under "Open Data" and "Statistics" / "Sustainable Development Goals". Data are also available on the MoF  KR website.
2-a-1.disaggregation: Indicator data are provided for the Kyrgyz Republic as a whole.
2-a-1.references_documentation:
Metadata available on the UN website: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/
Indicator Methodology available on NSC website: www.stat.kg
KR National SDG Reporting Platform: https://sustainabledevelopment-kyrgyzstan.github.io

8-5-1-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
8-5-1-1.indicator_name: Average monthly wages of women and men by type of economic activity
8-5-1-1.graph_title: Average monthly wages of women and men by type of economic activity
8-5-1-1.goal_name: 8. Promote sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all
8-5-1-1.target_name: 8.5 By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value
8-5-1-1.indicator_name1: 8.5.1.1 Average monthly wages of women and men by type of economic activity
8-5-1-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Labour and Employment Statistics Division)
8-5-1-1.definitions: The average nominal salary of the company's employees is calculated by dividing the actually accrued salary fund (both in cash and in kind) of the employees on the payroll (including part-time workers) by the number of employees used to calculate the average salary and by the number of months in the reporting period.
8-5-1-1.concepts: Average monthly salary for the month, quarter, since the beginning of the year and for the year; real wages adjusted for CPI.  ILO Convention 95 The term "wages" means, regardless of the name and method of calculation, any remuneration or earnings calculated in money and established by agreement or national legislation, which, by virtue of a written or oral employment contract, an employer pays to an employee for work that has been performed, or should be performed, or for services rendered. which have been provided, or should be provided
8-5-1-1.rationale_interpretation: The minimum wage is established by the Law of the Kyrgyz Republic "On the Republican Budget of the Kyrgyz Republic"
8-5-1-1.data_sources: Form No. 1-T (monthly, annual) "Labor Report" and Form Appendix No. 1 to Form No. 1-T (monthly) for November
8-5-1-1.data_collection: The collection of information on salary statistics is carried out on the basis of continuous statistical accounting. All legal entities, without exception, are subject to statistical monitoring of employees' wages. Form No. 1-T (monthly, annual) "Labor Report" and Form Appendix No. 1 to Form No. 1-T (monthly) for November are submitted by all legal entities (commercial and non-profit enterprises, institutions and organizations) of all forms of ownership. Small enterprises represent F. No. 1-FHD-micro (quarterly)
8-5-1-1.computation_methods: To calculate the average nominal salary of employees of an enterprise, the amount of the actually accrued salary fund (both in cash and in kind) is taken, as well as the number of employees on the payroll and non-payroll at the enterprise level, aiyl aimags, districts, cities, regions and the republic.
8-5-1-1.comments_limitations: They represent enterprises and organizations that have the status of a legal entity.
8-5-1-1.data_availability_gaps: The data are published in statistical collections "Kyrgyzstan in figures", "Women and men of the Kyrgyz Republic", "Social trends of the Kyrgyz Republic", "Statistical Yearbook", "Standard of living of the population". The statistical bulletin "Results of annual reports on the number and salary" is being issued.
8-5-1-1.disaggregation: By territory (republic, regions, districts, cities, aiyl aimags)
8-5-1-1.international_comparability: The methodology complies with international standards
8-5-1-1.references_documentation: The National SDG Reporting Platform of the Kyrgyz Republic: https://sustainabledevelopment-kyrgyzstan .github.io

10-3-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
10-3-1.indicator_name: Proportion of population reporting having personally felt discriminated against or harassed in the previous 12 months on the basis of a ground of discrimination prohibited under international human rights law
10-3-1.graph_title: Доля женщин, сообщивших об испытанных ими лично в последние 12 месяцев проявлениях дискриминации или преследованиях на основании, дискриминация на котором запрещена международным правом прав человека
10-3-1.goal_name: Goal 10. Reduce inequality within and among countries
10-3-1.target_name: 10.3. Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard
10-3-1.indicator_name1: 10.3.1. Proportion of population reporting having personally felt discriminated against or harassed in the previous 12 months on the basis of a ground of discrimination prohibited under international human rights law
10-3-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Department of Household Statistics)
10-3-1.definitions: Discrimination means negative or biased treatment of a person, or deprivation of certain rights on any ground.
10-3-1.concepts: The sixth round of the Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey identified the following grounds of discrimination: ethnicity /immigration, gender, sexual orientation, age, religion/belief, disability, any other ground. Discrimination occurs when individuals or groups are treated “in a way which is worse than the way people are usually treated,” on the basis of their actual or perceived membership in certain groups or social categories. It involves the group's initial reaction or interaction going on to influence the individual's actual behavior towards the group's leader or the group, restricting members of one group from opportunities or privileges that are available to members of another group, leading to the exclusion of the individual or entities based on illogical or irrational decision making].
10-3-1.rationale_interpretation: Discrimination can impede individuals from getting a fair and equal access to opportunities and services. These questions are designed to assess cases of discrimination and harassment against respondents that occurred during the 12 months prior to the survey. The questions include specific causes of discrimination and harassment, which may help respondents to remember the events. The current questions are based on the recommended set of questions at the beginning of the sixth round of the Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey.
10-3-1.data_sources: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS), Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS).
10-3-1.data_collection: This Indicator is based on the Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey (MICS) data. The data are collected for the target group - women aged 15-49 years.
10-3-1.computation_methods: This indicator means the proportion of persons who responded positively to the number of persons in the target group. The indicator value of the allegedly discriminated group is divided by the indicator value of another group. At the same time, the indicator calculates the proportion of women aged 15-49 years who have experienced at least one type of discrimination by the total discrimination cases based on each of the seven grounds over the last 12 months.
10-3-1.comments_limitations: The questions are based on the recommended set of questions available in the sixth round of the Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey. The questions may change based on the methodology developments to move the indicator from SDG Level III to SDG Level II.
10-3-1.data_availability_gaps: 2018 Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey in the Kyrgyz Republic
10-3-1.disaggregation: By area, urban/rural area, age, education, functional challenges, welfare.
10-3-1.references_documentation:
The Kyrgyz Republic SDG National Reporting Platform: https://sustainabledevelopment-kyrgyzstan.github.io
 https://www.unicef.org

11-5-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
11-5-1.indicator_name: Number of deaths, missing persons and directly affected persons attributed to disasters per 100,000 population
11-5-1.goal_name: Goal 11. Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable
11-5-1.target_name: 11.5 By 2030, significantly reduce the number of deaths and the number of people affected and substantially decrease the direct economic losses relative to global gross domestic product caused by disasters, including water-related disasters, with a focus on protecting the poor and people in vulnerable situations
11-5-1.indicator_name1: 11.5.1. Number of deaths attributed to disasters
11-5-1.organization_name: The National Statistical Committee (Department of Digital Development and Sustainable Development Statistics)
11-5-1.definitions: Death: The number of people who died during the disaster, or directly after, as a direct result of the hazardous event
11-5-1.rationale_interpretation: The disaster loss data on mortality is significantly influenced by large-scale catastrophic events, which represents important outliers in terms of mortality, as they normally imply considerable numbers of people killed.
11-5-1.data_sources: The Ministry of Emergency Situations annually provides consolidaterd information according to the state statistical reporting format No. 1-ES.
11-5-1.data_collection: Enterprises and Organizations, local self-government bodies, cities of regional significance report to the local state administration and district departments of the Ministry of Emergency Situations, then to the departments of the Ministry of Emergency Situations in oblasts and the city of Bishkek, then to the Kyrgyz Ministry of Emergency Situations.
11-5-1.computation_methods: Direct account on the number of deaths asb a result of emergency situation
11-5-1.references_documentation: The Kyrgyz Republic SDG National Reporting Platform:  https://sustainabledevelopment-kyrgyzstan.github.io

11-b-2.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
11-b-2.indicator_name: Proportion of local governments that adopt and implement local disaster risk reduction strategies in line with national disaster risk reduction strategies
11-b-2.graph_title: Proportion of local governments that adopt and implement local disaster risk reduction strategies in line with national disaster risk reduction strategies
11-b-2.goal_name: 11. Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable
11-b-2.target_name: 11.b By 2020, substantially increase the number of cities and human settlements adopting and implementing integrated policies and plans towards inclusion, resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, resilience to disasters, and develop and implement, in line with the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015–2030, holistic disaster risk management at all levels
11-b-2.indicator_name1: 11.b.2 Proportion of local governments that adopt and implement local disaster risk reduction strategies in line with national disaster risk reduction strategies
11-b-2.organization_name: Ministry of Emergency Situations of the Kyrgyz Republic
11-b-2.definitions: The indicator reflects the percentage (%) of local authorities of the Kyrgyz Republic that have adopted and are implementing approved disaster risk reduction strategies consistent with national strategies.
11-b-2.concepts:
Local authorities — aiyl okmotu, city mayors and district state administrations.

The Disaster Risk Reduction strategy is a document containing an action plan for the prevention and minimization of the consequences of emergency situations, coordinated with the national strategy.
11-b-2.rationale_interpretation: The indicator is used to assess the level of integration of disaster risk reduction at the local level and reflects the fulfillment of Kyrgyzstan's international obligations under the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030.
11-b-2.data_sources: Data sources: Administrative data of the Ministry of Emergency Situations of the Kyrgyz Republic, reports of local authorities on the implementation of disaster risk reduction measures.
11-b-2.data_collection: Annual data collection through official reports of local authorities, generalization and verification of the Ministry of Emergency Situations of the Kyrgyz Republic.
11-b-2.computation_methods:
Calculation method:

Share (%)=Number of local authorities that have adopted and are implementing DRR strategies/Total number of local authorities in the country ×100
11-b-2.comments_limitations: The data represents the number of local governments that have adopted and are implementing disaster risk reduction strategies, and is expressed in numbers and percentages. The indicator is based on administrative reports and reflects the actual number of such bodies as of the end of the reporting year.
11-b-2.quality_assurance: The data is being checked and coordinated with local authorities and the National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic.
11-b-2.data_availability_gaps: Data is available for 2019-2024, and there are no gaps.
11-b-2.international_comparability: The indicator corresponds to the global SDG indicator 1.5.4/ 11.b.2 / 13.1.3, the methodology is based on the Sendai Framework and the UNDDRR.
11-b-2.references_documentation:
Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030

Methodology for calculating SDGs 1.5.4 / 11.b.2 / 13.1.3 (www.stat.gov.kg )

National Strategy for Disaster Risk Reduction of the Kyrgyz Republic until 2030

1-5-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
1-5-1.indicator_name: Number of deaths, missing persons and directly affected persons attributed to disasters per 100,000 population
1-5-1.goal_name: 1. End poverty in all its forms everywhere
1-5-1.target_name: 1.5: By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters
1-5-1.indicator_name1: 1.5.1: Number of deaths attributed to disasters
1-5-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Department of Digital Development and Sustainable Development Statistics)
1-5-1.definitions: Number of deaths attributed to disasters.
1-5-1.concepts: The number of people who died during the disaster, or directly after, as a direct result of the hazardous event
1-5-1.rationale_interpretation: Large-scale catastrophic events characterize data on disaster losses. Reporting of emergencies allows for additional analysis to identify trends and patterns in which such catastrophic events can be prevented, thus contributing to sustainable development and enhancing economic resilience, social, health and environmental issues. Economic, environmental and social perspectives include poverty eradication, urban resilience and climate change adaptation.
1-5-1.data_sources: MESs provides annual summaries submitting the 1-ES Statistical Reporting Form.
1-5-1.data_collection: Businesses and organizations, local government bodies and cities of regional significance submit data to the local State administration and district offices of the Ministry of Emergency Situations, then to regional offices and the city of Bishkek, then finally to the Ministry of Emergency Situations.
1-5-1.quality_assurance: Each death attributed to disasters is confirmed by a special committee certificate.
1-5-1.data_availability_gaps: Data for Kyrgyzstan available since 2007 onwards
1-5-1.disaggregation: National and subnational level by gender.
1-5-1.international_comparability: Data for Kyrgyzstan are comparable with other countries as they are compiled in accordance with international methodology.

1-4-1.goal_meta_link_text: United Nations Sustainable Development Goals Metadata
1-4-1.graph_title: Proportion of population living in households with access to basic services
1-4-1.indicator_name: Proportion of population living in households with access to basic services
1-4-1.goal_name: 1. End poverty in all its forms everywhere
1-4-1.target_name: 1.4: By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance
1-4-1.indicator_name1: 1.4.1: Proportion of population living in households with access to basic services
1-4-1.organization_name: National Statistical Committee of the Kyrgyz Republic (Department of Household Statistics) under the UNICEF MICS global programme
1-4-1.definitions: Proportion of population living in households with access to basic services to total population.
1-4-1.concepts: Access to basic services implies that people are provided with sufficient, affordable and quality services that meet basic human needs: safe drinking water, sanitation and hygiene.
1-4-1.rationale_interpretation: Data on proportion of population of the Kyrgyz Republic living in households with access to basic services is fundamental to assessing progress in improving country’s standard of living. This indicator measures levels of access to basic services and ensures informed efforts of Governments to provide equitable basic services for all.
1-4-1.data_sources: «On the situation of children and women» Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey conducted in the Kyrgyz Republic in accordance with the rounds of MICS international household survey.
1-4-1.computation_methods: Proportion of population covered by social protection floors/systems = Number of persons covered by social protection floors/systems / Total population * 100
1-4-1.comments_limitations: Basic services also include energy, mobility, waste collection, health services, education and information technology, which are not considered in the indicator calculation.
1-4-1.quality_assurance: Data quality control ensured at all survey stages: toolset design, sampling, training, interview techniques, data control with weekly production of data quality tables, calculation of weights, calculation of indicators, report preparation. The audit was conducted by experts from UNICEF country, regional and headquarters offices.
1-4-1.data_availability_gaps: Availability of country assessments in accordance with the UNICEF MICS international rounds.
1-4-1.disaggregation: National and subnational level, location, wealth quintile.
1-4-1.international_comparability: Data are collected and produced in accordance with international standards and are comparable across countries.
